<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 294]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 278, 905, 294]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 386, 403]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 411, 719, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use a pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 254, 510]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 520, 760, 552]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 109]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE student is investigating the passage of light through a transparent block pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 526, 138]]<|/det|>
The student's ray trace sheet is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) to mark the incident ray. He looks through the block and places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) to mark the emergent ray so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear to be exactly one behind the other. He draws the outline of the block. He removes the block and pins and draws in the incident ray and the emergent ray.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 228, 892, 780]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 794, 532, 813]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 825, 146, 844]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 825, 180, 844]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 824, 897, 845]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, mark suitable positions for the four pins. Label the pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 848, 181, 867]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 848, 423, 867]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 865, 920, 883]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 178, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 814, 109]]<|/det|>
Draw in the line \(\mathbf{AB}\). Measure and record the angle of refraction \(r\) between and the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 118, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<form>r = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 149, 181, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 900, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 180, 920, 201]]<|/det|>

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
The student does not have a set square or any other means to check that the pins are vertical. Suggest how he can ensure that his \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) positions are as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 108]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE student is investigating the energy changes that occur when hot water are mixed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 752, 139]]<|/det|>
The student is provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 490, 170]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the cold water \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}} = 23^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 596, 201]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the hot water is shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 214, 816, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 273, 532, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 515, 324]]<|/det|>
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 335, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{h}} =\)  ............................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 146, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water. He briefly stirs the mixture and then records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture, \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}} = 49^\circ \text{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 181, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 816, 433]]<|/det|>
Calculate the gain in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the cold water using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 443, 564, 465]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{c}} = k(\theta_{\mathrm{m}} - \theta_{\mathrm{c}}),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 459, 363, 479]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 536, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
<form>\(E_{\mathrm{c}} =\)  ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 568, 181, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 567, 806, 588]]<|/det|>
Calculate the loss in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) of the hot water using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 598, 564, 620]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{h}} = k(\theta_{\mathrm{h}} - \theta_{\mathrm{m}}),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 616, 363, 636]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 693, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<form>\(E_{\mathrm{h}} =\)  ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 711, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 823, 109]]<|/det|> The student suggests that all the thermal energy lost by the hot water is gained Thus \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) should be equal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 180, 138]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 119, 870, 154]]<|/det|> State whether the experimental results support this suggestion. Justify your statement reference to the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 166, 918, 186]]<|/det|> statement ................................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 920, 215]]<|/det|> justification ................................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 255, 922, 274]]<|/det|>
.................................................................................................................... room temperature
starting temperature of hot water
use a digital thermometer
use only two or three significant figures for the final answers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 591, 92]]<|/det|> The IGCSE class is investigating the resistance of a wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 376, 120]]<|/det|> The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 128, 756, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 400, 532, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 146, 451]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 467]]<|/det|> A student measures and records in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across a length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of wire \(\mathbf{PQ}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 700, 495]]<|/det|> She repeats the procedure using \(l\) values of \(0.500 \text{m}\) and \(0.750 \text{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 180, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 616, 523]]<|/det|> Complete the heading for each column of the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 529, 181, 548]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 866, 551]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each length \(l\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 555, 489, 573]]<|/det|> Record the values of \(R\) in the table. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 586, 539, 603]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 616, 752, 727]]<|/det|>
\(l/\)\(V/\)\(I/\)\(R/\)

0.7501.610.32

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 672, 91]]<|/det|> The IGCSE class is investigating the formation of images by a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 358, 122]]<|/det|> Fig 4.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 134, 824, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 273, 532, 292]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 920, 386]]<|/det|> A student places the screen about \(1.0 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object. He records the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. He repeats the procedure using different values of \(u\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 761, 92]]<|/det|>
The IGSCCE class is determining the density of modelling clay by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 237, 122]]<|/det|>
Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 836, 153]]<|/det|>
A student moulds a piece of modelling clay into a cube shape as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 365, 532, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 181, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
On Fig 5.1, measure the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of the cube-shaped piece of modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 443, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h =\) ......................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 473, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<form>\(w =\) ......................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 504, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d =\) ......................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 181, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 612, 918, 633]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 644, 180, 663]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 640, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\), where the mass of the modelling clay \(m = 103 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 798, 920, 818]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) ......................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 238, 90]]<|/det|>
Method 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 871, 139]]<|/det|>
The student cuts the piece of modelling clay into two pieces. One piece is approximately the size of the other piece. The mass \(m_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the smaller piece is \(34.5\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.2a shows a measuring cylinder containing water. Fig. 5.2b shows the same measuring cylinder after the smaller piece of modelling clay has been lowered into it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 816, 125]]<|/det|>
Assuming that the experiment has been carried out with care, suggest two the two values obtained for the density of the modelling clay in (a) and (b) may same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 917, 180]]<|/det|>
1. .......................................................................................................................................................

2. .......................................................................................................................................................
